W5E_tH_9bvEHycwmXGCd_w.text: Ate here last night and had somewhat mixed views.. The food itself was really good, however the service left a lot to be desired. We were left hanging around whilst being shown to our table as the host stopped to talk to a member of his staff. We then were offered water for the table but was not told that this would be chargeable, our glasses were filled with still water and the bottle taken away, we didn't see the bottle again but we're still charged for the whole bottle. The waitress was very polite but also very distracted and in taking our order we were left worried that she would forget something as she appeared more interested in the other tables than ours. We declined to pay the optional service charge and on leaving were challenged as to why that was. The waitress was again very polite and we discussed our concerns but it was obvious she had been sent by her manager to find out why we did not pay..awkward!!

rbP_IZHrbuBzcA4GgsFtjw.text: Love Jinjuu!  My friends and I had such a great time there.  Everything we ate was delicious--very bold and interesting flavors. The space is very cool and hip, and our waiters were really attentive. Judging by how crowded the restaurant was, it's clearly the place to be in London.  Can't wait to go back the next time I am in town!

kM0Ke1wRagvy8xtTnNl3Ow.text: Seriously - give me all the food! The drinks are great as well - super friendly staff, and a cool venue to impress both friends and clients. Perfect London bar/restaurant combo if you are looking for somewhere with elegant service and style with no pretention.

7EarAj9EtRpKhCub7hNRxw.text: Jinjuu is a welcome addition to the London dining scene offering casual Korean dining in a fun atmosphere. It's a great place for groups and to celebrate occasions with its sharing concept, fun drinks and weekend dj. I highly recommend the Korean tacos (finally a place in london offers this!) and the Ssam platters. You also can't go wrong with ANY of the starters - I had to order another serving of the bibim salad when I went - and the carnitas fries is a must. The gochu bombs and sae-woo pops are also a nice representation of Korean comfort food. I don't think you can go wrong if you're looking for a fun night out with good food!

iyflMnclTAzcwRaNflByIQ.text: I can't say enough good thinks about JinJuu...I've been there twice now and both times have been excellent.Drinks - great cocktail menu, innovative and delicious.Bar - the bar upstairs is buzzy and has an amazing vibe. Love the DJ - totally adds good value to the atmosphere. Food - incredible!! Every dish is perfectly seasoned, with some incredible sauces and flavours. Definitely get the pork tacos, the fried chicken and the dumplings.Service - I was very happy when the owner of the restaurant came out after our meal to say hello to her guests. She is a gorgeous, lovely woman who was really kind and flattered to hear our praises.Great spot - I hope it stays exactly the same!Most importantly - the bar is open until about 1:30am and you can order food after midnight - which for London, which is shockingly poor at staying open late for decent cocktails and food - seriously made my night! This place is a goer!C

_oLQwJuvowueyr1a574yfQ.text: I enjoyed my time at Jinjuu, couldn't get a reservation in the dining room so sat in the bar area which was nice enough and they give you access to both menus though so no drama. The dining room wasn't full though so don't know why we couldn't get a table...Service was good, door staff and staff in general weren't overly warm, but our waitress was lovely. Kind, patient, informative and had smart waitress sense.Food was good, if not blow your mind amazing. We tried the fried chicken-good flavour, loved the radishes they serve with it, hated both optional sauces though. Dumplings were good, if I was to be super fussy, the pastry was thicker than I'm used to. The sauce they served with it was great, didn't need so much though and why serve dried stringy bits with it? Pointless and weird.Moving on, stuffed jalapeños were good, great dipping sauce, just super spicy! Que surprise. Bulgogi sliders were excellent, wanted more of those babies! Disco fries were OK, thought they would be better than they were, shame the fries were cheap frozen fries though, they also got very soggy from the juices of the toppings, so perhaps they should be laid out on a larger plate in a thinner layer so they stay crisper?Prawn cake pops were good too. Presentation of the dishes couldn't be faulted, nice sauces and garnishes without over-the-top fussiness and the food came out extraordinarily fast. Portion sizes were about right, value for money for the portion size was not.......I did find it expensive for what was on the plates, but what did I expect for the postcode right? Onto the cocktails, the menu is a Korean-jargon-filled list of foreign ingredients, which sounds fun, but gets tiresome when you actually want to choose a drink. I ended up going for a mango-coconut vodka combination which was nice and had the citrus notes as promised by the menu, but why on Earth would anyone decorate the glass with dessicated coconut? The glass was an old fashioned shallow but wide glass so you have to hold the glass at the stem or use a straw. Plus the coconut gets EVERYWHERE, whether or not you are trying to sip the drink. Good idea in theory but not thought out, the glass got super sticky by the end of the drink and I'm no messy pup.This place has made me more interested in Korean food, I would like to try something more homely in style next time but its certainly a good option for drinks and snacks, just not on a budget.

bSz5HHvPD3HvwCDNCERljw.text: I didn't have any really great food in London but there were a few worth mentioning. We tried this place Jin Juu owned by Iron Chef UK Judy Joo in Soho. It was pretty busy even after the lunch time. We ordered the Jin chicken to start - Korean fried chicken. It was freshly fried, mixed with the secret soy sauce. The chicken was pretty juicy, not bad. But £8 for 4 pieces of chicken thighs, pricey.Next, we had the Bibimbap with seasoned veggies and fried egg (£8). Taste like any normal Bibimbap, nothing out of the ordinary. Finally, we tried the kalbi beef (£20.5), served with white rice, seasonal leaves, & toasted seaweed. The kalbi wasn't like the ones they usually serve in Korean restaurants - the ones with the bones on it. But the beef was sliced like steak. It was interesting to wrap them in cabbage leaves and rice. The beef wasn't bad, but I think I prefer the beef short ribs with the bones.It wasn't a cheap meal but based on the other restaurants we have tried in London, this is one of the better ones.

Pqcr97-0Z_Mi4qxe75ndog.text: Great food and atmosphere! Highly recommended. I have been already few times looking for all the sharing dishes in the menu. Carnitas fries, small burgers or fried chicken, chocolate brownie ... are amazing. it is also one of favourite places for cocktails in London together with great DJ's every weekend.Perfect place!!!

uFQ0m2SbZF1ov1eir4lCvQ.text: Not a bad spot for a casual bite with a group of people. But if you know Korean food, don't expect that. This is more toned-down fusion like Korean food.

jSeQnWLzpDDP4i2Cj4j3xA.text: Already can't wait to come back again, I have a checklist of things I still want to try! First of all the presentation of the dishes themselves made my mouth water. I was really craving Korean food, which is not the easiest to find in London, and I was so excited to have secured a table for dinner.I'm not sure what others were complaining about, the portions were just right, no need to eat to the point of waddling out the door. I ordered the Jin Chick and the bulgogi bibimbap. The chicken was perfectly crispy yet tender to eat, with the just-right-pickled moo (white radish) to go with it.The dolsot stone bowl along with all the fresh ingredients perfectly adorning the rice was exactly what I needed to really hit the spot.I'm eyeballing the bo ssam, kalbi and mandoo for my next visit along with that gochugaru brownie! Mmmmm.

Z9x0ES7OrN_THfMDwzuq4g.text: Great restaurant, delicious food!! Chicken is highly recommended. Very hip scene. Can't wait to go back.

HZM-Qbn_MVoDV-_qU3T6Aw.text: I popped into Jinjuu for a quick lunch and ordered a Bibimbap with crispy tofu. As a Korean, I've tried my fair share of Bibimbaps and this place is now Top 3 on my list of best Bibimbaps.  I love the fact that the food has that Western twist but without compromising on the authentic Korean flavours. Highly recommend it to everyone!

4-4uPpAmluJBlUlQdioeLA.text: The chicken is the jewel in the Jinjuu crown.  I've gone back time and again just to have it and have told anyone and everyone I know to try it atleast once.  It's absolutely finger licking great!!  The decor is lovely, the service is fantastic and the prices are affordable and in line with the caliber of food you get. The bar is well stocked and the mixologists make great drinks.  there is a great Sunday deal and they do take away. Enough said in praise of the is place...just go and try it!

rt65KIf41ataaSj_OSSBHw.text: I think 3.5 is more appropriate.  Overall I really want to like it.  I think most of the menu is well priced, well presented, and the service I received on both occasions was pretty good.  The soju even with locational mind I think is at least £3 too expensive for a bottle. I've had the carnitas fries, fried chicken thighs, Bo Ssam, bibimbap with bulgogi, and yook hwae.  Overall well presented food and I absolutely love the fries, I will keep coming back for those, but my complaint is that everything seems over seasoned.  I don't like either of the sauces that come with the fried chicken. Ssamjang for me bumps up the seasoning when eaten with unseasoned Korean bbq not with seasoned fried chicken.  The crisp batter isn't what I think of when I eat fried chicken but I definitely see the tip of her hat to the Brits with the way it's battered. I just wish there was a bit more of a sweet, spicy element rather than so aggressively savoury. Bo Ssam fell flat in so many ways, you need oysters for Bo Ssam even if it's and additional surcharge, ditch the ggim on the salad platter, have your server explain all sauces (and understand their kimchee, the runner had this very wrong), and don't serve it cold!  Bibimbap was ok but again I think over seasoned.  Yookhye my gf enjoyed but other than the quality of beef I wasn't excited.  Observing the wait staff downstairs there is still work to be done as it looks a bit clumsy at times, but our server was pretty good.  I will go back again and again for the fries and to try new things hopefully my review update will be more delightful.

photos.caption: Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Fried chicken
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Carnitas fries
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Bo Ssam

exVNS94355bgECTRCSOFoQ.text: First of all, I have lived in Korea and am a lover of Korean food. I've been to many/most of the London Korean restaurants and was very excited about trying Jinjuu.I tried to book lunch online through their website (OpenTable) but was unable to so called and left a message. They called me back within 20 minutes and said I could sit at the Bar.The location of the restaurant is good, right behind Regent St./Carnaby St. The decor is excellent - very modern, industrial, with exposed lighting, a lot of steel/rough surfaces. The bathrooms (downstairs) are very cute - with K-Pop posters and old Korean government safety/health posters on the walls.The menu(s) were fairly extensive, but somewhat confusing with a lunch, dinner, anju (side dish) menu as well a separate drinks menu all provided.The dishes were a mix of traditional Korean favourites (e.g. Japchae, Bibibimpap, mandu, kimchee, etc.), as well as some fusion dishes (e.g. Scottish mussels with white wine, dwenjang and bacon!). We ordered Japchae, Korean fried chicken, Bibibimpap, a side dish of kimchee and corn (popcorn) tea.The service was generally good, with the utensils and presentation sophisticated. The quality of the food was mixed though.The Japchae was very salty (we had the vegetarian plate), but still edible. The Bibimbap and Korean fried chicken were both good - particularly the quality of the beef and chicken in both. The kimchee was frozen! After complaining, it was replaced quickly.Overall it was a good meal, reasonably priced. I still think they are having some teething problems. I am keen to try again at night - when I think the style/decor would really shine through.Glad there is a new, sophisticated Korean restaurant in London.

Eoib7JgyzZNy_MNoL_G0MQ.text: Amazing food for reasonable price! Environment very comfortable as well. The special chicken is really tasty

8-nObSon21zB3Z1UZJoquQ.text: We ordered several small plates including the sae-woo pops, plus the bibimbap. All were great items, though some of the spices did start to repeat themselves a bit. Maybe this was just due to the items that caught our eye, hard to say without going a second time. They also have a great drink menu - highly recommend The Interview.

UCoNg2N--End1Ikxezu6Dw.text: Jinjuu is now one of my favorite restaurants in London.  I love the contemporary twist on Korean food. It's a flavor explosion!  My favorites are the saewoo pops, bi bim salad, fried chicken, short ribs, mushroom tacos. After one bite of the snickers dessert, all my friend could say was "holy moley!" Cocktails are also creative, using traditional Korean liquor and Asian flavors elegantly. After 9pm on sat, the bar had quite a cool scene and good music so you can linger after dinner.  Service was attentive and friendly.  Decor is hip and industrial. Highly recommend jinjuu!

ujZoAg385S10lJb-MJh4mA.text: Went for a few drinks and some nibbles - prices are standard for anywhere in central London; quite a nice place with a fairly Korean ambience.

6TA_jMP6RF7jf9AmwdhjVw.text: Visited Jinjuu with some old friends on a random Tuesday night.  It was by far, one of the best experiences I've had of late.  We were looking for some drinks and nibbles and Jinjuu definitely didn't dissappoint!  We took the opportunity to sample through the drinks menu and found our favourite, the Bourbon Baby.  While we went through these libations, we also sampled the wonderful food!  My favourite was the Korean Fried Chicken.  It's the best I've had outside of NYC. The atmosphere was buzzy and the service was fantastic.  We'll definitely be visiting again!

EhRsJ5W1XIAayAv18d7K9w.text: I went to Jinjuu last night with a girlfriend to have a catch up and a nice meal in Central London. It's so difficult finding a restaurant in W1 to eat freshly made food, has an ambience and where you don't feel like you're either sitting on someone's lap or they are earwigging in on your conversation. Jinjuu is my dream come true! Awesome food, gracious service, cool decor and a buzzy but chilled environment downstairs. My friend was running late but it didn't matter to me because I was so comfortable in a nice booth and it gave me time to peruse the menu. I must have studied that menu for over 20 minutes because I couldn't decide what to order because there were too many tempting dishes to choose from! My friend doesn't eat red meat so I didn't get the Korean disco fries because it has pulled pork but I'm definitely getting them next time!  I did have to order the pork belly tacos with Apple slaw and I ate both of them all by myself! They were absolutely delicious and what I loved most was I was expecting them to be quite sweet but they were the  perfect blend of moist tender naturally sweet pork, a bit spicy sauce topped with that fresh crisp tangy Apple slaw - absolutely divine! We also had the home made prawn crackers which were absolutely out of this world ! salty, spicy, crunchy, perfect! We also had the Korean fried chicken wings with the two different sauces, again absolutely perfectly fried chicken that didn't taste greasy at all.  We also had the Korean Caesar salad with grilled prawns which was divine. You could tell that the prawns were fresh and not frozen because they tasted sweet and not rubbery. Oh yes and we also had the tuna tartar with the fried lotus root-  I think was one of my favourite dishes of the evening! We also had a small bowl of white boiled rice which was cooked to perfection, bit sticky and I had sesame seeds on top as well-  Yum! Which reminds me the other super highlight was the veggie dumplings. The dipping sauce was freaking delicious and the black and white sesame seeds just made each mouthful a flavourful sensation. You'd think that we had enough with all those small plates but of course we found room for desert. We ordered the Snickers doughnut which had a fancy name but all I remember was that it was a snickers doughnut. When it arrived, it was a deconstructed dish, so there was a small round plain donut, some chocolate ganache, nougat  ice cream and some sprinkled  chopped nuts-  put all together on a spoon, absolutely amazing like a snickers flavoured donut! We actually didn't drink any alcohol that night but I had some delicious mint tea which really really went well with the dinner. I should mention that the presentation of the dishes, the type of teapot my tea came in plus the cups were all very tasteful. Jinjuu is the kind of restaurant that I can go with my husband, go with a group of girlfriends, or bring work colleagues to. I haven't been this excited about a restaurant in a long time. I'm so happy I've found a central London spot!

q7LzTRtMzy6X9Qf6NO9MRQ.text: This place was great fun. The cocktails were excellent, the food was better. We had the Interview cocktail to start. Highly recommended. Food-wise we had so much fun with each course as another adventure. Sae-woo pops, fried chicken wings, beef bulgogi tacos, tofu sliders, dumplings, shrimp skewers and jap chae. All tasted great with the sliders and chicken wings everyone's favorite.

NquGwejXCOwejlqkPZS5cQ.text: Excellent food, quite unlike other Korean restaurants in London. The interior is a little dingy and tries too hard to look cool (K pop posters in the bathrooms!), and the food is not cheap. However, I have always had delicious mains and starters here.

pAt3D-T6BAXIvltbTp1uHA.text: I was in London for work for 2 weeks. My family came with me for the first week and we were lucky enough to pop in and grab a meal. We were seated upstairs and ordered a bunch of small dishes and then shared a main. (Note that there are 2 pages to the menu! We almost didn't notice it, and that would have been a pity.) Of note are the sae-woo pops (fried prawn balls on sticks) - so delicate and perfectly fried. We also had the bulgolgi sliders, steak tartare, and short rib and kimchi mandoo. My son, who can be hard to please, especially liked the sliders and mandoo. I usually find Korean dumplings to be bland but these were especially flavorful. The slight sweetness of the pears in the beef tartare was a pleasant surprise. My son was stuffed at this point and wanted to save room for dessert, but my husband and I decided to plow ahead and have the bass ssam. Never had a fish ssam before and this was so incredibly good. Light, delicate, perfectly cooked. I wasn't able to sample much of the desserts because of a nut allergy, but my son and husband tried the gochugaru brownie and the chocolate mandarin ice cream. Portions were very generous. I love little details like the crispy chocolate rice that came with both desserts. They were so tasty.When my project was completed, I came back with my team to celebrate. We were seated downstairs which I ended up preferring as it was quieter and we got a view of the open kitchen. Since we were a larger group (and it was on the company), we went all out and ordered a lot more. I feel like we ordered half of the menu. We had the prawn crackers, kong bowl (I want to know what that seasoning is and if it's available for purchase!), carnitas fries, tacos, chicken sliders, fried thighs and wings, steamed mandoo, a salad, noodles, short rib ssam, sirloin ssam and the bass ssam (yes, again, it was that good). There may have been more. I can't believe we finished almost everything and then got a tasting plate of desserts to boot. The chicken was juicy and tender, the short rib and sirloin ssams were melt-in-your-mouth delicious. It was a great meal to end my trip. Oh, and the drinks. I can't believe I forgot to order the Bloody Mary. I did have the bourbon drink and the negroni, both were excellent. Don't forget the bathrooms. Spam doors. Love it.Not sure when I'll be back in London but there are more dishes on the menu I want to try. Like the Bloody Mary and the roasted pork belly bossam.

StymsdQjURRLxb7kZShWgQ.text: It's a hip cool K-pop kinda place. With pretty girls having dinners and fancy cocktails. Food is alright, nothin special or type that will make you wanna come again. The most disappointing part is that I've been sitting here for 40 minutes and haven't a seen any of ordered dishes. And they kept bringing food for my date but not me which is kinda weird and wrong. Nice service okay food ( cause I tried some from my date's plate) but NEVER COMING BACK AGAIN.

photos.caption: Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. My foreverly empty plate.

PJi5fEbJA4LcSOCsLpwyyw.text: I had high expectations going in but was disappointed. I'm rounding up -- I'd give it 2.5 stars. First, I found the menu and the food neither authentically Korean nor creatively fusion. Awkward in-between. Take the bulgogi tacos, for example. As much as the thought could be appreciated, I felt like the heaps of Mexican ingredients overpowered the true star of the dish (bulgogi). Furthermore, I would have expected more creativity from the menu based on all the buzz, but did not see anything that I hadn't seen before. Second, ambience was also so-so for me. I could feel that they were trying too hard to be trendy and fashionable but without achieving neither class nor the cool factor. The rooms generally seemed to follow the "classy" code, but the wallpapers in the loo were distasteful and almost trite. Once again, awkward in-between with no sense of true identity. Finally, one thing that was good was the service. Waiters were polite and prompt. I'm so saddened -- I was hoping this would become my new go-to, but it fell far short.

ps6JNBWIH2XgaTu61FN4sw.text: We are traveling from the states and we scoped out places to eat and found Jinjuu prior to arriving in London. I couldn't be more excited to have found a Korean fried chicken place near where we were staying as I am a Korean American. We get to this place, and seeing how packed it was, I had high hopes. That feeling was long gone after we sat. We were stuck with a terrible server who barely acknowledged us and treated us with complete annoyance when we didn't ask for anything other than an extra spoon. There was a big group next to our table, and the way he treated us compared to them was alarming. He was all smiles with the group and while serving them, he didn't check on us once, even to ask if we were doing okay while being inches away. He also stood there while I was trying to pay in cash which made me really uncomfortable. Once I put cash on the table, he immediately took it without saying a word. He didn't even thank us or asked us how the food was which was mediocre to say the least. The chicken was nothing I had hoped for and the raddish had way too much vinegar, taking away the fresh and raw taste it should have had. I usually am not this specific but he was unacceptable. By FAR the worst server I've ever had including the ones I've encountered in the states. The only thing greasier than the food was our servers hair! Watch out for the blonde highlights!

VUuk7JrZYOptpt0tbTPb5g.text: Pretty great Monday night meal with a friend - great, edgy ambience in a fun part of Oxford Street - I know I will be back to this area, if not to Jinjuu specifically because of all the cool pubs and restaurants in the areaCocktails - I got a white negroni made with soju which was really nice and mixed well with the vermouth Starters - bulgogi tacos and pork mandoo - both were good and especially like the spicy chili sauce that came with the mandoo - they kept it on the table so we could have it with the other dishes as wellMains - famous fried chicken and japchae (vegetarian) - I always judge a Korean place by its japchae since I love this dish and can never get enough of it. The japchae was quite good if a little greasy. The fried chicken, on the other hand, was perfect - great crunch, not too greasy, went well with the sauces they gave - would highly recommend thatDessert - Korean mocha - really nice chocolate tart with salted caramel praline - would recommend this dessert for all chocolate lovers Service was great and not too rushed - we had a good time here and I would definitely recommend for friends and come back myself

_kEE6xyxlMTUPO78QyYEWw.text: Our first experience was in SoHo, absolutely lovely staff and good food with an interesting menu selection! It was a great experience. Then we tried the Mayfair location, and we went away so disappointed it was puzzling! Wait staff weren't as friendly as the SoHo location and the food just didn't have the same excitement either. The menu is just a bit different in Mayfair, but can't put our finger why we left so...Blah! However, will definitely recommend the SoHo location.

9ldD12Ubauu704TQ9KygpQ.text: Delicious food but not authentic - despite what Judy Joo says - and let down by terrible service. The food is great but it is a twist on Korean using elements of Korean flavours to deconstruct dishes and make them into something more trendy and modern. I thought it was delicious but if you want authentic Korean this is not the place. Try one of the small Korean places in and around Holborn or venture out to New Malden for a totally unique Korean home cooking experience. While the food was great, I can't give it more than 3 stars because the service was SO bad. We sat and were immediately asked if we were ready to order - we were only given 2 food menus for 5 people and, despite asking, were never given more. We asked the waiter to come back and it took him ages to do so. We ordered and I had a question about the menu. Instead of answering it the waiter said "I have other tables waiting for me - hurry up!"  I told him I couldn't order if he didn't answer my question and he rolled his eyes. Finally he answered the question about substituting the prawn pops on the tasting menu for something else as I can't east shell fish by saying "I can't imagine that there is anything we can do for you. Just let someone else eat that one and you can try to swap it with them for something they don't want."  I asked him to check with the chef and after telling me he couldn't imagine the chef would care, he finally asked. Of course, the chef did care and made arancini for me instead, which were very good. During the meal, the waiter kept trying to take our plates away while we were still eating and we had to ask him not to rush us. He seemed to retaliate by then having each new course take 30 minutes to come out. We finally asked the manager, who came to check on us, if he could see where our food was, and even he said that he couldn't imagine what was taking so long. He brought the main courses himself but then it was another 30 minute wait for dessert after those plates were cleared. It was a tasting menu so all the food was ordered at the same time. The manager again had to check on our dessert. Dinner ultimately took 2.5 hours! It also took ages to get our bill as no one ever looked in our direction and people walked past us despite trying to flat them down. The only good service was from the food runners who took time to explain what we were being served and recommend how to mix the many sauces, etc. The food was good but not spectacular (everything was quite salty too) and, with service like that, we won't be back.

yypNVk_LAludG0zk8907vw.text: Food was excellent, service patchy and the building alarm went off about 6 times. Manager came over after about the 5 time it had gone off (was very uncomfortable noise) to apologise for the noise and asked if he could get us anything, me said "that would be fabulous thank you and asked for a bottle of Resling. . £29.50. Thought it was free but it got added to the bill. Staff English not great, but they are very attentive. Would go back again.

DJcWs5sE_izgBNBH53lbRA.text: A mediocre experience at one of Kingly court's premier Korean establishments. Tatler magazine rated the place as one of the top places to eat in soho, and I'd have to disagree. I think the ambiance was definitely top notch, since we had an open window seat on a warm evening. My friend visiting from abroad enjoyed Soho, and we had a nice dinner. I just think the hype and definitely price didn't live up to its name for me. I'm a big fan of a fair deal, and sadly I feel that JinJuu just didn't deliver top notch food for its pricey menu. The drinks were all right (and strong!) but definitely not worth the price. £11 cocktails is a stretch even in London. We eat a lot of Korean food in Hawaii, but I felt that this joint just didn't live up to my expectations. I think I just wanted a little less glam and a little more Korean oomph and goodness! Definitely a good place for a flashy night with friends though.Edit: the service was amazing though!!! Nice people as always

fIiZJcJDKeOizc0cMSX6Aw.text: One of my friends wanted to go there so badly after all the review she had hear so spending some time in London, we book a table for a girls catch up at Jinjuu. First impression when I enter the place: how the waiter can serve you there? There is hardly space between the table. Anyway , we had a small table at the corner so best place if you don't want to be disturb to much with the passage way. We decided to go for starter to share so we had the same woo prawn: excellent, the carnitas fries: really chilli and really good, the small / cute tiny burger: beef and chicken, excellent, chicken wings : the sauce on it was really and vegetable dumpling: so nice. We were 3 and really hungry. It was fine to share starters but the portions of the starter were smalls and the cost was high so not really cool and had to go for more or something else. So if you are really hungry one of 2 starters and then go for a main. As Said, my friend was still hungry so she ordered a bibimbab with beef , I have tried it, it was really good. Finally and that was actually what I should have start with: the cocktails! Lots of choice, original Taste and really well done. Forget about the normal wine and try one the their cocktails you won't be disappointed. So in conclusion it's a nice place, the food  and drinks are good but the price is way too high for Korean food which is not exceptional! We end up with a bill of £105 for only 3 people and they even ask for £13 service charge on top, way too much! So nice but too expensive.

photos.caption: Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Cocktails : the green one is with basil and elder flowers. Sorry can't recall the name for / and the other one!
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Carnitas fries
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Sae woo prawns pop

NTNhJSzHg3My2cVhRGGqlQ.text: Jinjuu is catching a wave right at its crest here in London -- Korean cuisine is on the come-up thanks to accessible menus at places like Bibimbap and Korrito. Both of those places are aiming at an authenticity that Jinjuu isn't interested in: this Korea fused with America and Mexico, and it mostly works. Sorta.Given the month that we waited for a reservation to open up, we expected Jinjuu to be packed and boy it was. The tables are closer together than you expect in London, which I suppose gives Jinjuu an authentic New York or Seoul feel right from the get-go. The music is loud and the lighting is dark -- it doesn't really feel like fine dining and if you find you've got a headache on the day of your Jinjuu reservation, sell your table booking on eBay.The food is nothing less than interesting. We got the Jin Chick signature chicken wings, which were cooked beautifully with nicely crisped skin, but the bold spicing I expected was a timid background flavor instead. Nothing's going to beat Barnyard for the London chicken wings cup anytime soon. The beef bulgogi tacos were a big step up with a surprisingly tasty combination of flavours, but the bibimbap was unexciting and served in an insufficiently hot stone bowl.The weirdest thing on the menu didn't live up to its potential: the carnitas fries are delicious wouldn't be out of place on the menu at Boho Mexica or Wahaca -- you can't taste the kimchi at all.Jinjuu is a perfectly nice place to have dinner, but you'd struggle to identify it as a Korean restaurant if I brought you there blindfolded. Although if they just turn the lighting down one more notch we won't need the blindfold.

yZlkxZYECJ2QLZekBeNuRQ.text: I went to Jinjuu on the recommendation of a work friend and I was glad that I followed his advice! The only thing he said was 'try the tacos' so this was just one of the many dishes my friends and I tried that night.   The beef tacos, the carnitas fries and the bibimbap bowls were all delicious and are highly recommended. We also tried to the tempura vegetable plate which was also really good. The tofu was the best I'd ever tasted but the batter was a little heavy for my taste. The only thing we ordered that I wasn't that fond of was the g-something bombs. Essentially, a jalapeno with meat and cheese inside. I didn't find the filling that full or flavorful and again, the batter was a bit heavy for my taste.   On the whole we had an excellent time and I'd highly recommend the cocktails too. The servers were friendly and attentive which is unusual for a 'cool' establishment.

QiOtw2W_1pRKBQg0vYXLsw.text: Big fan of Judy Joo so was excited to try her restaurant in London.  I went there a couple of weeks ago as I didn't want to be part of the big hype etc.The Korean fried chicken is the BOMB, you can get wings or thighs... GET THE THIGHS... they're fillets in a very crisp batter and probably my favourite dish of the night.we had the prawn lollipops with the spicy mayo.  Funky presentation but nothing extraordinaryI had the bibimbap (beef) which was good... though I was truly hoping for more crispy bits in the bottomand the other dish was the Korean barbeque (ribs).  A good slab of meat but I found the meat quite dry.  The lettuce leaves were all torn and not very fresh so they couldn't really hold anything almost at all.The disappointing dish was the hottok... which is the Korean donut.  I have seen Judy make this and what came on the plate was completely different and disappointing.The hottok was COLD very very stodgy donut with really dense dough. would definitely NOT get that again which is really a shame b/c I had very high hopes for it.The service is spotty - waiters kind of hang about as if they don't know their surroundings and when you ask them for say a bit more kojejang... or more water... it either never comes or comes when you're paying the bill... so not very impressed.Overall nice vibe and I am really glad I went.  loved the fried chicken but not much else for the price.  I will not be rushing to go back.

K4aAhbrqdmLVA9o2Iahsfw.text: A good glass of wine followed by delicately made small plates of Korean food? What more can one expect in this big city! Their food was creative, simple and had the perfect touch of flavor and quantity to keep you satisfied. Their tofu burgers, kimchee rice and drinks are amazing! A perfect place for a date night ! Jinjuu you have done justice to Korean food...until next time!

_kgY7vpM6WlztivJRYSdXA.text: I went with a group of friends and we shared several of their small dishes. There was a good range of options and everything came out perfectly cooked. The beef tacos and chips were particularly good. So why only 4 stars? The food whilst good wasn't amazing and seemed expensive considering what we got. Also the service was slow and staff unfriendly. All in all though I'd be happy to go back.

OrflP8KNJ0p_9vqdc4oYSA.text: I'm just speaking about the cocktails here, as I left food for another time (it's difficult to think about eating here when you have pilgrims two doors after down on the road!)On a nice sunday afternoon, my lady and I were looking for a place where to spend an hour or so without being in a pub, waiting for our stomach to prepare for an amazing pizza. And my lovely yelp app gave me the address of this place, which we promptly tried! and we were satisfied with our choice.The menu is ranging over 3-4 pages of soju-based drinks (for anybody wondering, soju is a classical korean alcoholic, comparable to a "rice vodka"), some wines (short selection actually I was expecting a bit more!) and few classical cocktails. But my suggestion is definitely to go for a soju cocktail, this is one of the few places in London serving them and you want to check them out! When we ordered our drinks, the waitress nicely suggested us a different cocktail for a "first-timer soju" and we followed her suggestion, I love whenever a waiter is doing that "extra-mile" for suggesting something more tailored on yourself!The cocktail we ordered, K-POP pornstar (yep, their range of names is pretty awesome!), was a wonderful combination of sweetness from the passion fruit and the bitterness of sparkling soju, something I loved!We will surely get back here for dinner, if they care about food as much as they do care about drinks we are in presence of something wonderful!

SGVXQcQ2m4Mdqt_HddZkig.text: Loved the food! More like a bar so not a lot of food choices, but for the ones they have the taste is awesome! Good atmosphere too!

photos.caption: Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. The bar
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom

hTUUkh9kpgq2FJE8NSOGzw.text: This restaurant offers amazing, modern interpretations of classic Korean cuisine.  The cocktail menu is also fantastic.  If you are in London there are many dining options but definitely consider dining here.  Reservations are essential and should be made as early as possible.  I recommend the pork-belly bossam- outstanding.  Outdoor seating is available in warm weather- haha, I know, I'm talking about London.  Look for Chef Judy Joo's recipes and cooking show.  Anyplace outside of London, Paris, etc, this is five stars.

KVJce9_2A3tuXcIgnYFbig.text: What a really fun night!  We had planned to grab drinks elsewhere before our reservation but when I looked at the menu we made a change to try the bar here.  GOOD DECISION!  Not only were the drinks really really good we had quality banter with the bartender.  Once seated we enjoyed a number of the small plates and tacos all of which were excellent we also had beef skewers and the chicken sliders that were fantastic.  A very interesting wine list (we had a Portuguese red and some kiwi white) rounded out an excellent evening.  One thing to consider is that as the night goes on the music gets louder and louder.  By the end of the evening we were pretty much shouting.  Not a problem for our group but something to remember.

f0lIYG_kwc2rk8IthSdL5g.text: From the moment you enter the staff are very welcoming. The decor great. Was lucky enough to be able to have lunch here today. I tried there tacos, had the beef ones and fried chicken Korean style. I decided to try there Jin juu salad everything I ordered with the help of the staff was amazing. I'll go back with a group of friends so we can sample more from the menu. The drinks menu looks fun lots of cool cocktails. Go here!

photos.caption: Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. K pop in the bathroom
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Korean flat pancake
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom

Mre69Xrz7R-BPDKM4P91Xw.text: Awesome bibimbop!!! Great service. We walked in and were struck by the ambiance. Our waiter gave us our sliders for free because our friend couldn't eat dairy and he had been mistaken that our sliders had none. Honestly the best service we've gotten in London.

hECYeu8ATueQktrtU_pkMg.text: This place is chic and delicious. I wish Jinjuu was in NYC. The prawns were amazing and bursting with a spicy flavor. The brownie is uniquely prepared with sweet yet spicy kick.

photos.caption: Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Asian pear salad

-eTCGzauHg0ScB_e0sxqEw.text: This is my second time here and to be honest my first experience wasn't great hence when my friend suggested here I wasn't overly excited. However something seem to have improved however I am still not a big fan of the beef Bimbimbap.. The marinade just don't do it for me. However we tried the pork and the prawns today and the pork had a lot more flavours going for it.. We also ordered some starters to share,  the prawns style cake pops,  those were yummy the chilli mayo was good but I would prefer the hot sauce that came with the fried chicken. Which was also yummy.. Finger licking good.. They had a whole fried chicken which served 3-4 but we weren't there just for the fried chicken so we only went for the thighs and wings mix. The mocktails are also delicious... I got the jinjuulicious and I really like the combo they had.. With a cough clearing I thought something with some friendly bacteria yakult will definitely help! We also ordered the kimchi plate.. Boy I could do with a bigger portions.. Cause the size of the serving is a little on the small side. I would definitely go back for some more of the starters for sure!

photos.caption: Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Chap jae
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Bimbimbap
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Prawns pop

ufPtUVBsLk-is7ElkUwHPw.text: Ooh a sexy spot for a date night dinner! We splurged on the 7-course signature menu - though that's really not as extravagant as it sounds as it should really be called the 7-dish dinner! I love trying new things, especially of the foodie variety, so I loved that it taught me what things like kimbop were (the Korean answer to sushi don'tcha know ;) as well as mandoo and sae-woo pops. The 'main' dishes were tricky but fun to eat, needing to be assembled and wrapped up in lettuce leaves so a very hands-on job!Our server was so polite and chatty, and would always engage with us with a little comment or anecdote between every course. It was just a shame it was tricky to get his attention. The drinks were also very slow to appear as I think they come from the bar upstairs. I thought overall it was pricey for what it was, but I did like the surroundings a lot and it was certainly humming nicely on a Saturday night. Don't miss the loos if you visit either - Asian boyband posters aplenty in the ladies (and I was told something a little naughtier in the men's!).

NTptZhx03749sDS347kNGg.text: YES. Yes. Yes. Yes. Finally! Jin Juu, you have been in my list for oh so long and wow was it worth the wait! I had tried to book a table for 2 online but they said they were fully booked, I thought sod it, I'm going anyway - I will get a table. My friend and I arrived around 7 o'clock and we were seated straight away (mini fist pump) and right by the open window - it was a lovely evening. We were very happy.The waiter greeted us immediately with a welcoming smile and some fresh water. As my friend and I hadn't seen each other for a while we were mattering away for a while - the waiter came over a couple of times to ask for our order which wasn't a problem and we eventually made a decision and ordered. I have to say that throughout the evening the waiting staff were very friendly and attentive and it was an overall lovely experience - even when it was becoming a little cold, they quickly whacked on the heaters and made sure we were comfortable! Now to the food, it's advertised as Korean street food - if they are selling this on the streets inoh the food. For starters we ordered the mandoo dumplings (beef and pork) and the Kimchi Arancini - the food came at a good speed and was presented beautifully. The dumplings were mouth-wateringly wonderful - truly meaty in the centre and wrapped in a tasty and slippery casing. Quite difficult to eat with the mental chop sticks but I got there. Scrumptious. The kimchi balls too were amazing. A soft rice and cheesy centre and coated in bread crumbs - just delicious bites of goodness.  Next, the mains. We both opted for the Jap Chae (sweet potatoe noodles) - I had prawns and my friend had the beef. The food once again was presented beautifully and served with fresh veg. The prawns were cooked beautifully and there were LOTS of them. I also tried the beef and it was tender and very flavoursome. The noodles too were delicious and you tasted the freshness in every mouthful!!What a meal and what an experience! Truly fantastic and I will be back to try more of their delicious menu!!

photos.caption: Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Open bar
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Beautiful open reflective restaurant
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom

2j85lIQ8zTmcSP-nqIeVWQ.text: Having visited Jinjuu Mayfair last month which we loved was very keen to return so today we dropped in on Jinjuu in Kingly Street and even though the Restaurant was busy they were very accommodating and found is a place. The waiters were very friendly and the service was very good. There is such a wide choice of delicious things to have but we decided on in a lightish lunch . We started with really tasty Pork Belly Tacos then some Carnitas Fries followed by Korean Fried Chicken which is amazing to finish we had a delightful Korean salad with Prawns and Asian Slaw . I would highly recommend a visit to ether Jinjuu for fantastic Korean cuisine #food #restaurant #korean

photos.caption: Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Asian Slaw
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Carnitas Fries
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Korean Salad with Prawns

tIRN1kpG-z_W0Lv_DUrPIA.text: Ate here last week and the service was just not as good as my 1st visit in August 2016 (which we loved and couldn't wait to go back).  The waiter this time was not as attentive and helpful this time.  Food was just ok.  My main issue was the so called steamed "sea bass" we ordered.  Sea bass is much more meaty type of a fish (chilean sea bass or even black sea bass), what we got was a piece of filet that was very short (approx 6 inches in length) and thin.  I know fish and this was like trout.  I asked the waiter about it and he was certain it was sea bass and he said he will ask the chef to be sure but when he came back with my bill, he didn't say anything about it.  At that point I thought it was useless to argue so I just paid the bill and left.  I felt I was being taken with the food and will definitely not be coming back here again.See my review of August 29, 2016

Vyl3Sa1SfPd7Me-Q0EX36A.text: Dining at Jinjuu on Kingly Street next to Carnaby Street. Korean food with a western twist. The food is good, perfectly spicy enough for me. In the photo is the Thinly-sliced Pork Belly Bibimbap. Also had sae woo seafood lollipops, fried chicken, beef dumplings, kimchi fried rice. The highlight for me was the delicious Aloe Vera Cha (tea). The music is good here, and the service too. Overall, a pleasant meal  Next time I'll choose a different Korean restaurant to get the more authentic experience and taste. Jinjuu recommended me a discount upon arrival do I did get a £10 discount here by using the Velocity IOS app. Ended up paying £60 for 2 people who walked away stuffed and feeling good.

photos.caption: Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Pork belly bibimbap

z67s6WZ5dNj_0z-o7jDkgA.text: Finally ventured into this delectable place for my birthday lunch two weeks ago. My google maps took me the long way round, but it's just off regents street If you're not too sure. Lucky I booked a table, as it was relatively packed for a Sunday! Sat downstairs in the main dining area, facing the kitchen, and on top of the hooded fan, they have a lovely quote board. The walls are all designed to fit the Korean theme and jinjuu itself which means "Pearl" it has a clean, modern layout, with table booths and normal comfy seating. Been following on instagram for a while now, and the food looks tantalising. I ordered the kong bowl - so morish, yummy, and not too spicy, just the right amount. Very generous with the portion too. I loved the Sae-who pops, they reminded me of my cake pops. They were so good, my favourite. Of course when you're at jinjuu you have to order the kfc - Korean fried chicken, I went for the thighs and they were served with two cute little sauce bottles, dark soya and gochujang red chilli. OMG seriously!!!!! The best fried chicken I've ever had, undoubtedly the bestest!! I'd go back just for that. Also ordered the ya-chae mandoo - vegetable dumplings and wow, such cute presentation! Served in its own canape spoon with the sauce and all you do it dip the spoon into the sauce and eat it in one bite! The best Korean food in London by far!!!!! Judy Joo I love you!!!! I wanted to stay for mains but my tummy was at the brink!! Service was exceptional, everything was explained and also what drinks to match the dish too. Cutlery on the table was so neat, the gold chopsticks and soup spoon, attention to detail! The bar staff themselves are very polite! I am returning very soon and looking forward to checking out the HK branch too I'd highly recommend this as one of my top 5 spots in London!!!!! Also the cocktails are exceptionally yummy! :)

photos.caption: Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Ginee in a bottle #yelplondonrainbow
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Ginee in a bottle and zap #yelplondonrainbow
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Ya-chae Mandoo - vegetable dumplings

lw_gVdQfrk2R1ba-JuyLgg.text: Another fantastic meal at Jin Juu! A friend and I popped in on a busy Friday night just before 8 and were lucky enough to get a seat inside (there were a few damp cold tables outside).We just wanted a quick bite so went for 3 sharing dishes and a glass of wine each. The food is served as it is ready so first up were the chicken sliders. They are amaaaazing! A must try. Next were the carnitas fries that I had raved about from my last visit. They were good but definitely not as good as last time - less toppings and not piping hot. Our third dish was beef dumplings - unfortunately these took nearly 30 mins to come following the rest of the food. After all that I didn't think they were anything special but my friend thought it was worth the wait - a complimentary glass of wine each and a sincere apology made up for it :) The food and waiting staff always impress me and they were so busy I can see how slip ups happen in the kitchen. I'll be back!

photos.caption: Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom

18sfvcWlNuFV0CM94GOnkg.text: This is not korean food. I repeat: not korean food. I ordered their fried chicken, I think it was about 40% breading and 60% chicken. Their dumplings lacked flavour and Soju was just mediocre. Which is unfortunate because the place does have a nice snappy ambiance. I wouldn't come back here, for those of you looking for korean food take a few extra steps towards chinatown (e.g. Little Seoul) if you fancy having a proper korean meal. Besides the food not being great the service was also unfortunate, they seemed to be all over the place and rude when I mentioned my chicken was not ok. It was just an observation, nothing for the hand-tattooed waiter to get upset about.. Maybe some time in HK but never again in London!

photos.caption: Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. "Bulgogi" skewers
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Fried chicken, not that good

-0KpMNBlxvJr9gvDsvPbRg.text: I was in town for work and wanted to eat something that reminded me of LA Korean food. I didn't mind the fact them at this place is fusion. Totally catered to the modern person who knows that authentic Korean isn't always an option. I honestly don't know what the standard is here in London. I'm not trying to come across pretentious either. Just I like what I like and I dismiss the things that I don't. What I do recommend is the bibimbop, tuna taco & cod saam. The dumplings are so so, the raw beef is mediocre, kimchi fried rice was too buttery for me. It's ok. I really like the ambience and the staff is super attentive and sweet. If you're looking for fusion, this is it.

photos.caption: Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom

M4Z8JCSMh7wopsOOCjsVZg.text: Amazing asian fusion restaraunt!I came here with my dad for dinner not expecting the food to be out of this world, only because I am korean and my mom cooks authentic (secret recipee type) food at home all the time. We tend to always compare other korean/asian food to hers, because her food that she makes is in fact out of this world. Here at jin juu we had a great experience. I love there tacos. They are absolutely amazing. My favorite taco is the tuna (raw tuna) taco. The tuna is so tender and soft and it melts in your mouth. The mini sliders are also a favorite of mine. The beef and chicken sliders were absolutely delicious. The spices and sauce they use to flavor the sliders are awesome too. That is what makes the slider so amazing. Their kimchi fried rice is pretty good too. It comes with an egg on top. The only thing i didnt like about the kimchi fried rice was that there were small pieces of sausage in it. I wasnt a fan of that. Lastly, the jap chae wasnt very good. It was way too salty and was flavoured with way too much soy sauce. I could not take another bite. However, my overall experience here was perfect. Great staff, great ambiance, great music/vibe and great food! This place is a must try for anyone with a hankering for some asian food.

J3gzApj0mg76j_e5PaTXsg.text: Could Korean food be the next hot food trend in London? Although there are already well established hot spots like New Malden, chains like Kimchee and OntheBap are bringing fast Korean food to the massesI had seen Jinjuu chef Judy Joo on the Food Network and decided to give them a try as I'm a big fan of fried chicken and am still looking for someone in London to match Bonchon in San FranciscoJinjuu had a very trendy, hip vibe despite me visiting at lunchtime and service was efficient throughout. I was seated downstairs and able to watch the chefs at workI spied an interesting £45 tasting menu but that had to wait for another day as I wasn't in a mood to splurge that day. However, I did pick 2 dishes off that menu - sae-woo pops and Korean fried chicken thighsThe sae-woo pops were 5 deep fried prawn cakes, which arrived on sticks, served with a side of creamy gochujang mayo for dipping. For those unfamiliar with Korean food, gochujang is Korean hot sauce and a staple of Korean food and cooking. Nice and crispy but the mayo reflected one weakness of Korean food for me - their hot food tends to be hot without much other flavouring to round it out, so you just get heatA bonus mark for using thighs in the fried chicken. So much more juicy. The chicken was crispy and served with pickled white radish on the side to give some contrastAn enjoyable meal and that tasting menu is interesting enough for a return visit but my top fried chicken is still at the Lockhart in Marble Arch

photos.caption: Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Korean fried chicken thighs
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Sae-woo pops
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom

07zt0vp3yzxmVB6lzGufDw.text: One of my favourite restaurants in London and highly recommended. I get a craving to return monthly and that hasn't worn off after 4 visits. The menu has loads of great things to try and I wouldn't sway you away from anything, but I do have some favourites. There are quite a few, so go with friends, share and enjoy!The Sae-Woo Pops-GREATThe Carnitas Fries-AMAZING-imagine amazing nachos, but instead of crisps it's chips-Perfect!Tacos-GREATBulgogi Burgers-AMAZING-Some of the best sliders I have had anywhereKorean Fried Chicken-GREAT-Their speciality, but not my favourite dishAdd in another portion of tacos and Sliders and the above would feed 2 easily, I always go for some Prawn Crackers as well!Drinks wise, they have a great cocktail menu...the K-Pop Pornstar is my favourite.Top 3 tips for this place-1.Book if your going in the evening-it gets busy2.Orders lots of the smaller plates and try as much as you can3.Give their cocktails a try, they are well worth it

photos.caption: Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Carnitas Fries-Jinjuu
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Bulgogi Burgers-Jinjuu

rHqh6Z4Iz4Nkm21bU14Apg.text: Excellent service. Delicious food and great presentation and attention to detail. Reasonable prices, and friendly staff

photos.caption: Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Vegetable Dumplings
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Delicious

urx8CRp5zzPSRYHU4aYWfg.text: Phenomenal. Traditional favourites with innovative twists. Amazing cocktail menu. Incredibly friendly staff. So glad we came!

W261Q0ov4xz7ctgBoPAcXg.text: I was looking for a place to eat late on Sunday as nearly every restaurant was closed in soho. As a result jinjuu gets five stars for availability. The wings were amazing and the bowl was extremely filling. The staff was very friendly and even stirred my bowl for me. However beware that if you do get a bowl be sure to stir or have it stirred immediately or the rice on the bottom will burn. I would surely go back when I am in town

ND-0TVTDiPrEq7kGn1dAug.text: I don't think I will come again to this place.1. The food is just normal Korean food with a bit better look... 2. The price is too much and I don't get why I'm paying 3 times more for the same Korean food...3. The staters are messy and the fried chicken is really dry and hard... The beef is like rubber...4. The Korean food is just not Korean at all... It doesn't take you anywhere close to Korea... But like some western people tried really hard to make Korean...5. The service is poor in quality, they are wondering and looked very busy... Everyone is all of the place, but just don't serve and got get you the bill when we need to go...Period.

R8PtnLNrGPvxi2tRd2SDgg.text: Great location.  Just off carnaby street. The food was excellent. Had the korean fried chicken 5*  also the short rib and kimchee  mansion and Asian slaw were great! Staff was very lovely! If you like korean food  ... you should pop in for a meal!!

LEjN3mVNe-t2lZat5IWt1w.text: Amazing place to try once in your life! When booking a table, I didn't find availability online, but managed to reserve a table over the phone for the following day. The place looks great from the outside, but when being seated, there is not much room to slide between tables. but once seated, its very comfortable. The cocktail menu is interesting. I had the k-pop pornstar & Lychee lover. The food is presented very well. My favorites are the carnitas fries, sae-woo pops and bibimbap bowl. The Carnitas fries are very spicy. The bibimbap bowl has a lot going on and is filling if you are hungry.The only real negative is that I found it very noisy, so was hard for me to concentrate on listening to my friends conversations.

photos.caption: Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Mushroom tacos, tofu sliders and saw-woo pops
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Bibimbap bowl with sauteed prawns

hF0YDXJbiWAhVTV0OvUNlQ.text: My new favorite restaurant and even better is that it is KID FRIENDLY & THE FOOD IS DELICIOUS!!! Staff were all super friendly and helpful ~ Although you can't tell from the exterior. Looks very sophisticated and trendy not kid friendly but looks are deceiving because it was very kid friendly. Everything you love about Korean food X 1000! No fillers just the good stuff. Thank you Jinjuu for exceeding all our expectations

HY3XPnxame1IzyTC-EcIxg.text: First favorite restaurant in London.  Stopped here after searching for something different.  This is it. Think Korean fused with outher cuisines.Service was 6 out of 5 stars, food was 5 stars, and the price was fairly decent (expected).  Bonus for having a kids menu with adventurous options for kids such as Bibimbap, Korean kids soft drinks, free special character chopsticks for the kids, a large menu of cocktails, wines, sojus, and beer.Our entire family loved it.My wife ordered the beef Bibimbap, and I had the kimchi Bibimbap. We split a soju as it can be strong, but later we switched to me having the top shelf shots and my wife had lychee infused soju.  So good!We booked on OpenTable and we're seated immediately.What really stands out is the diversity of cross-cuisine food combinations such as Korean Tacos.  We would definitely come here again.

photos.caption: Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Dessert!
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Dumplings Platter
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Bibimbap with Kimchi

7LdbAzG0YKY_-i495nZ5bQ.text: Mediocre Korean fare in postcard perfect Soho. I really had high hopes for Judy Joo's joint, but found myself less than satisfied. Small portions. Small flavors. Even the banchan was weak. Maybe I expected something more traditional. Not my cup of soju.

photos.caption: Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom

7cdKNWCXP_q0xB9ylw5rmQ.text: What a fantastic meal! The four of us enjoyed so many appetizers and a number of main entrées, all of which we shared. Each and every one was outstanding. And if you like spicy food, this is totally your place, should you decide to opt for spicy. Aside from incredible food, the service was outstanding. The staff could not have been friendlier. The atmosphere was also quite fun and hip. Love this place. Try it out.

h4vCXcGl47UYKtJhMpYGWw.text: What a cool little bar in soho! There's so many pubs around but we decided to venture out and go to Jinjuu! The decor is very modern and hip. It's a great place for drinks with friends. Everyone got something different but the highlights were the Ring Leader (drink of the month) and the Kimchi Mary (Korean twist of the Bloody Mary). It's a bit pricey but stop by here for a few drinks.

photos.caption: Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Lychee lover
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Ring leader
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Spiced kimchi Mary

04xoV5V2FeOiH9InIeSBPA.text: Jinjuu is another one of my favorite bars in Soho. This place is quirky and the drinks are unique and delicious. The bartenders are usually very friendly and fun to chat with. From sweet drunk me to bitter ones, I've liked all the drinks I've had here. If you aren't getting food, you have to sit at the bar, but I've never had too much trouble getting a seat.

B70D_IYoA9y0XcN_ARY0mw.text: Excellent night out in the Carnaby Street area of London at this Korean restaurant.We were a group of 5 and were entertained to a feast of flavoursome food ranging from Kimchi Carnitas Fries, tuna tacos, Mandoo (steamed meat dumplings) and the very tasty Bulgogi beef skewers.We ate towards the back of the top floor seating area at a 'sociable' table and were further entertained and assisted by our waiter Kelvin throughout our stay.The food is very tasty and at about £50 pp service and VAT included, including 2 bottles of wine and a couple of soft drinks not bad value for money.I would definitely go back again.

photos.caption: Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Jinjuu
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Arty shot
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Jinjuu menu

HVCN8RAEVZcQxzITuRccGg.text: Very average. Service was so so and the bibimbap was mostly rice. Ice cream dessert was just ice cream. Really unimpressed

zLv3VgOTfoblNmRZ_oABKQ.text: One of the few places in the area that offered awning for outside seating and since it was raining we popped in for some pre-dinner wine. The service was friendly and very tolerant since we switched tables-no problem! They served a bowl of spicy and not so spicy crisps which was nice to munch on.

photos.caption: Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Paul and Steve
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Adult libations pre-dinner
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom

kIMVdfqlsvA3qxqw-HC_Hw.text: Happening place.  Great vibe.  Never thought Korean food would become so posh and cool.  While, I miss my mainland Korean food or Los Angeles Korean food, whenever I am in London I take the time to check out the new generation of UK Korean food.  It's amazing that the non-Korean staff are pretty knowledgeable about Korean food.  I will admit that I still know more.  But definitely a great place to make a reservation and visit.

NJVSIIGQ-D71vsllmxu_Xw.text: This place has the best Korean food in London! I came 2 nights in a row. The menu allows you to try several small shareable bites, and service was top notch. I would recommend this place if you are looking for a great place to eat in SOHO!

peERJnJJUbPg-qJfa-S3XQ.text: So excruciatingly bland in flavour and confused in it's style. The waiter was lovely, food was hot and quick, the cocktails delicious. But I have to wonder if the chef tasted the food. I vote no.I thought that this was a Korean restaurant. Vegetable crisps with guacamole?Corn salsa?Cheesy chips?I do not compute this fusion.Had to skip the sweet potato noodle as I have never had a plate filled with so many items taste completely of nothing.Amazed the reviews are so full of praise. I must stress that the highlights was certainly Antonio the waiter. The amount of food you get for the set menu price is great, and perhaps it was a rare glitch on the day we eat where all the seasoning went missing.

igfG_CBma1q7YuGUKv3Ynw.text: A spin on Korean food!If you are looking for cheap traditional Korean food then go to bibimbap or bibigo.However, if you re into a westernised twist on Korean cuisine this is your spot. Mind that the service is very slow but staff is very nice not that it makes up for the slowness. The food was well seasoned and presented. I adored the beef tartare with Asian pear.The japchae was good but not enough noodle for the price.My friend had the bibimbap and thought it was too much rice versus meat and veggies. I didnt taste it.The desserts were hit and miss too.I had the makgeolli and white chocolate panacotta  with mango compote, passion fruit and yuja jelly and lychee sorbet. it was an absolute delight, a must order.My friend had the Korean Mocha.This was too heavy in chocolate and the texture of the dessert was too dense, I would not recommend it. Finally the drinksThe cocktails are really good and unusual.I would recommend the bird is the word as a pre-dinner drink and the white rice negroni as a post-dinner drink.Overall, I would comeback but mostlikely for drinks and sharing some anju dishes

photos.caption: Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. White rice negroni, a perfect after dinner drink!
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Korean mocha. Order only if you are a chocolate lover and you are still very hungry because it is very densed in texture
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. The best dessert of the night: makgeolli and white chocolate panacotta

RJTYAOdrkG56Xrz8GJIjxQ.text: Soo many great options to share. We had 4 small and 1 large between the 2 of us. We had pork belly tacos, fried chicken sandwich, dumplings, bibimbap and salmon sashimi. The dessert was excellent too. The cocktails were super interesting as well.

photos.caption: Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom

MuCM5aJs9LYXJW1zRAgffg.text: An interesting twist to Korean food. We ordered:Sae woo popsYa xgae mandooKorean fried tofu burgerKimchee fried riceOverall, pricey but enjoyable. There was a lot I wanted to order but this was my second dinner. I kept stopping by other joints on my way here; I wish I didn't so I could have ordered more! The menu is very interesting. I recommend coming on an empty stomach. The staff wasn't very attentive; it took forever to get their attention. Free wifi! Lots of seating.

photos.caption: Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Kimchee fried rice and meat dumplings
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Veggie dumplings

N5ESsFTdfgVbJgv_ANP4UA.text: We had reservations to eat at Jinjuu after catching a play at the Gielgud theatre. Jinjuu is one of those fusion style restaurants opened by a celebrity chef, and I really enjoyed my experience there!We ordered the Pork Belly Tacos, Pork Mandoo, Bulgolgi Sliders, and the fried chicken thighs to split between two people. My personal favorites were the Pork Belly Tacos, they were fantastic! The Bulgolgi Sliders were delicious as well. The fried chicken was actually my least favorite dish (I found it to be a bit too salty in taste, which is strange because it is supposed to be their signature item).For drinks, I had the Spiced Kimchi Mary, and I could definitely taste the kimchi. It was a unique twist on the typical Bloody Mary, and I quite liked it.Atmosphere inside Jinjuu was pretty trendy, with plenty of young 20s/30s people out for food and drinks on a weekend evening. Service was attentive, and the server did a good job providing recommendations on what to order.Will definitely return to Jinjuu in the future for a night out for drinks with the girlfriend and/or friends!

photos.caption: Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Mandoo
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Pork Belly Tacos
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Spiced Kimchi Mary

WqVg90kCZXFhO2jLSuJCsA.text: What a gem of a place.Amazing fusions within Korean and oriental flavours. The small plates were interesting and very rich, specially the mushroom tacos.For mains the Korean fried cauliflower was something. Flavours were good but not out of this world. Amazing cocktails options and very creative. I tried the interview and k-pop pornstar ( even the names were funny). Definitely recommend and visiting back soon.

V-xkZPzw6P3rbef6ltLGhQ.text: Jinjuu blew our freaking minds. I've ordered take-away here a few times after figuring out that the cooking show I love watching is actually owned by Judy Joo. So cool! So, I've had their Jap Chei and Bibimbap. When my husband and I came we tried a few dishes and they were not only delicious, but uniquely different, beautiful and holy crap so yummy. Kimbap- basically warm sushi and delicious, fresh, and lightYa-Chae Mandoo- vegetable dumplings- the dumplings themselves were silky and delicious, but the sauce that went with it wacked the dish up to a flavoursome mouthful of happyKong Bowl- yummy edamame Jap Chei- absolutely phenomenal! The noodles were warm and slippery- it doesn't sound so appetising but the flavour is so wonderful and at the same tim t's all so light! AH! I seriously love the textures and the flavours. The atmosphere and service is also very nice as well. We will be back.

photos.caption: Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Edamame
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Jap chei- amazingly good
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Veggie dumplings

eLBhZtd36B5uq4dzCWWVrQ.text: Nom, nom. It's Korean fusion trendy style. Loved the sliders!!! Definitely get and the shrimp pops. Great ambience in there and pretty spacious. It was kid friendly as well with the waiter giving our little kid chopsticks! How sweet! Oh yea, don't forget to get the braised ribs. Done perfectly!

photos.caption: Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Shrimp pops and sliders. Yum!!
Photo of Jinjuu - London, United Kingdom. Kid chopsticks!

g95Woj1VYDzajPQZxTvtAg.text: This place is excellent. I love Korean food, but are here the first time around for drinks only, and just had to come back. The cocktails are excellent, all with little korean twists, featuring ingredients like lychee and lemongrass, priced reasonably, and very very easy to drink. There is indoor, bar and outdoor seating, with polite and attentive staff. If I dined here again, i'd definitely get the sea food lollipops, the kimchi fried rice or the sweet potato noodles, and some of the gorgeous pork dishes, particularly the dumplings, which are absolutely packed full of tasty.
